Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Batteries Enabled by Novel Nanostructured Scaffold Electrodes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to have advanced lithium-sulfur batteries enable increased range of electric vehicles with lower cost. One of the most challenging problems in electric vehicles is the short driving distance and relatively high cost, which have been mainly caused by the performance of the current Li-ion batteries. These batteries are good for small electronics such as cell phones and computers, but their energy densities and prices do not meet the current demand required for large scale systems. The proposed battery technology can achieve an energy density five times higher than those of the current Li-ion batteries as well as lower the manufacturing cost.

This I-Corps project will further develop a process technology that enables sponge-like three-dimensional carbon nanotube bulk materials while maintaining the properties of individual nanomaterials. With this novel scalable synthesis method, the junctions/contacts between carbon nanotubes are seamlessly connected by covalent bonding, ensuring excellent electron transport across the junctions/contacts. Typical methods for commercial carbon nanotubes result in powdery materials which necessitates additional manufacturing processes to make practical bulk materials. In comparison to the conventional methods for making battery electrodes, the novel manufacturing method used in this project results in electrically conducting scaffold electrodes with large surface areas, eliminating inactive binders and conductive additives in batteries, which allows for remarkably increasing the energy density of lithium-sulfur batteries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developing high-energy-density and low-cost batteries has been driven by the increasing market demand for use in transportation, portable device, as well as the electric grid. The high price and relatively low energy density of the currently widely used Li-ion batteries do not meet the demand. As electric vehicles are expected to be popular near future to replace automobiles with internal combustion engines, efficient electrical energy storage systems with high energy density are in urgent need. Newly developed Li-S batteries whose energy density is at least two-fold higher with a much lower cost. The cathode is enabled by a sponge-like carbon nanotube bulk, which is invented by the Entrepreneurial Lead and the Principal Investigator.

There must be some applications urgently expecting high energy density storage solutions. Targeting such customers and market will significantly promote the business development during the starting stage. The value propositions that stand out from current battery providers were studied. Strong selling points keep the technology competitive in the market. Product expectation from the potential customers gave which battery specifications are most important. Delivering high performance prototypes are crucial to the customer relationship. After interviewing many customers, the fact is that the customers who is urgently expecting new battery solutions are willing to pay more if the products can satisfy their demand. We pivoted the value propositions to high specific energy battery products, which are drones are used in hobby, military and commercial applications. At the same time, commercial drone users are targeted as the entering-market customers since battery energy density limited their performance and other markets are very hard to get into at initial stage.

This project has provided diverse training and professional development opportunities to the participated graduate student. For the professional development, the principal investigator and business consultant well demonstrated how to interview the potential customers with key questions and insightful conclusion from the interview outcome. The student’s social communication skills are significantly developed. Business skills developed in this project will also benefit the student for the future career. The newly developed exciting outcomes were disseminated to the current battery manufacturers and investors. This technology will be transferred to a company for industrial scale mass productions, which will provide invaluable knowledge as well as an exemplary model for practical use of nanomaterials. Furthermore the new findings in battery manufacturing and fabrication for higher energy density will be disseminated through research papers in respected journals.


Last Modified: 02/11/2018
Modified by: Choongho Yu
